Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: Impacts of Food Processing on Diet-Induced Thermogenesis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
All human societies regularly process their foods by thermal and non-thermal means. This feature distinguishes humans from other species, and may even be compulsory from an energetic perspective, given that we possess relatively small molars and gastrointestinal tracts that commit us to an easily digestible diet. Yet the energetic significance of food processing and its evolutionary implications have barely been considered. This study tests the hypothesis that thermal and non-thermal processing lower the metabolic cost of food digestion, known as diet-induced thermogenesis (DIT). Effects will be evaluated for tubers and meat, foods widely exploited by humans and believed to have been critical resources for ancestral hominins. In theory, processing of these foods should result in a loss of structural integrity that lowers DIT due to reduced chewing and gastric effort, as well as increased access by digestive acids and enzymes. Since heat should weaken food structural integrity to a greater extent by gelatinizing starch and collagen, it is further predicted that the effects of thermal processing will exceed those of non-thermal processing. To evaluate these predictions, energy expenditure data are collected via respirometry from subjects before and after standardized meals served raw and whole, raw and pounded, roasted and whole, or roasted and pounded, based on a counterbalanced within-subjects design. Rats will be used as model organisms in the interests of low cost and high control, but a subset of trials will be replicated using human subjects to validate the animal model.

This study will quantify the impacts of thermal and non-thermal processing on DIT, an important factor in energy balance. Results will improve our understanding of the energetic returns of food processing and inform models of hominin transitions toward higher dietary quality. Low DIT has been implicated as a factor in the development of obesity. By determining the effects of food processing on DIT, this research contributes basic data that could help consumers influence the partitioning of meal energy to metabolism versus body stores. Results will thus be communicated broadly to peer-reviewed journals and conferences in anthropology and nutrition, as well as public forums. This doctoral dissertation research project will also contribute to the professional development of a female graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research into the energetic consequences of food processing has focused largely on its role in increasing bioavailability, the percentage of food calories absorbed within the gut. However by disrupting the structural integrity of food items, food processing might also be expected to increase net energy gain by reducing diet-induced thermogenesis, the energy spent on food ingestion, digestion, absorption and assimilation. Diet-induced thermogenesis arising from unprocessed versus processed diets has not previously been quantified in mammals. In this project, we employed open-flow respirometry to measure diet-induced thermogenesis in adult rats fed standardized meals of lean beef or sweet potatoes that were served either raw and whole, raw and pounded, cooked and whole, or cooked and pounded. For both meat and tuber foods, we found that food processing by pounding and/or cooking substantially reduced diet-induced thermogenesis.

The results of this project have improved our understanding of the energetic significance of food processing in the past and present. With respect to the past, our findings have informed alternative models of how humans became biologically committed to an energy-rich diet over the most recent two million years of our evolution. With respect to the present, this research has contributed basic data that could ultimately lead to recommendations that help consumers influence the partitioning of ingested calories toward heat production (i.e. loss) versus body stores. The potential benefits to society are especially great in this case because the calorie values reported on food labels in the U.S. do not presently account for diet-induced thermogenesis.

We have begun to communicate our findings in public lectures, invited academic lectures and professional conferences. We are currently preparing a manuscript that details our methods, results and conclusions and we anticipate submitting this manuscript to a peer-reviewed journal shortly. Due in part to our findings on this project, we have also organized an international symposium, entitled "Why a Calorie Is Not a Calorie and Why It Matters for Human Diets," to be held at the 2013 Annual Meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS). Our symposium will highlight the disparity between the calorie values reported on food labels and the energy gains actually experienced by the consumer. We hope that by drawing attention to this disparity and discussing potential remedies, we will help to stimulate work toward more accurate public reporting of nutritional information, thus allowing consumers to make more informed choices regarding their caloric intake.
